predicted_answer: The seed lexicon is a small set of words manually labeled with affective polarity used to train a model that propagates polarity to other words in the sentence; in the paper, it contains 100 words selected based on frequency and association with positive or negative sentiment.

The proposed method achieves an accuracy of 82.2% on a test set of Japanese sentences without manually labeled data, outperforms a baseline method, and improves supervised learning results when labeled data are small.

Discourse relations are used to propagate polarity by linking words or phrases that have the same affective polarity, and the proposed method uses a seed lexicon to assign affective polarity to words in a sentence and to propagate polarity from the words with known polarity to the words with unknown polarity.

The Japanese data used in the paper is a corpus of 1.5 million sentences, collected from news articles, blogs and social media posts and pre-processed by removing stop words and punctuation and normalizing the word forms.

The available labels for supervision in the dataset are affective event labels and discourse relation labels, which were used in combination to train the model that propagated affective polarity and achieved an accuracy of 82.2% on an unlabeled test set.
